page.title: 02RIVER AVILL
page.content: It was written in 1183 that Dunster had a port and it seems that small boats could come up the river as far as the castle. Probably as the boats got bigger and the river gradually silted up, the harbour was moved further down towards the sea. In 1565, "Dunster Haven" was listed as a place at which small boats could land salt, wine, food, wood and coal but when port facilities were developed at Minehead, the harbour at Dunster was used less and less and today there is no harbour at all. The River Avill also gave the power to work two flour mills. The lower mill has disappeared. The upper mill was rebuilt in the early 19th century and has recently been restored and is making Dunster flour and people can visit the mill to see the mill at work.
